RESOLVED_ENTITIES.United States Court of Appeals for the F: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the Court: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Court: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Court in this context: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country being differentiated from police states, with constitutional protections against unreasonable searches
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court that refers to the lateness of the hour as a relevant consideration in determining reasonable suspicion, has previously made decisions regarding stops on Interstate Highway 35
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Government: government whose enforcement agents, including border patrol agents, are bound by the Constitution's prohibition against unreasonable searches
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol: law enforcement agency whose agents conduct stops and searches, including roving border patrol agents like Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron, and observe behaviors such as occupants avoiding eye contact or trying to hide, with subjective perceptions of appearance varying greatly among agents
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: court reviewing the issue of stops by border patrol agents, has made decisions upholding stops by immigration agents that have come close to ignoring fundamental constitutional concepts
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexico Border: reference point for distance calculation in determining reasonable suspicion for stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Brignoni-Ponce Standard: legal standard or precedent used to determine reasonable suspicion in immigration inspections and stops, may be satisfied if other articulable facts reasonably warrant suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court Jury: jury that was given the Allen charge after indicating deadlock, deliberated for approximately three hours after receiving the charge, and requested a clarification of the United States district court's initial instructions
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Federal Courts: courts that have not favored interrogations of jurors except where there is some showing of illegal or prejudicial intrusion into the jury process
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: defendant in the case whose motion to interview jurors was denied by the United States district court judge, owner of a pickup truck used in the case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia's Vehicle: pickup truck driven by Maria De Jesus Garcia, subject of a stop and search by border patrol agents where occupants exhibited suspicious behavior, including hygienic appearances that were considered in assessing reasonable suspicion for the stop, had an apparent heavy load which was considered as a factor in determining reasonable suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate Highway 35: location where previous experience with illegal alien traffic occurred and where the stop took place, known for being a common smuggling route
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court Judge: judge who denied a defense motion for mistrial and instructed the jury to continue deliberation, made oral findings of fact regarding the constitutionality of the stop and search, has sound discretion in deciding whether to give the Allen charge, also refused Maria De Jesus Garcia's request for post-verdict discovery
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Allen Charge: charge given to the jury to encourage continued deliberation after a deadlock, its giving was alleged as an intrusion into the jury process but held not to be error
